\[\begin{aligned} \left| \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^3} - \sum_{n=1}^k \frac{1}{n^3} \right| \leq \frac{1}{20000}.\end{aligned}\]

Or, equivalently,

\[\begin{aligned} \left| \sum_{n=k +1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^3} \right| \leq \frac{1}{20000}.\end{aligned}\]

Interpret this sum as a Riemann sum of a certain integral that you can compute.

question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
We want to find the smallest k such that

\[\begin{aligned} \left| \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^3} - \sum_{n=1}^k \frac{1}{n^3} \right| \leq \frac{1}{20000}.\end{aligned}\]

Or, equivalently,

\[\begin{aligned} \left| \sum_{n=k +1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^3} \right| \leq \frac{1}{20000}.\end{aligned}\]

Since all of the terms in the sum are positive, the sum itself is positive. So, the absolute value signs are unnecessary. Note that

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=k +1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^3}\end{aligned}\]

can be interpreted as the right Riemann sum for the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int_k^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^3} dx.\end{aligned}\]

Since \(1/x^3\) is monotonically decreasing, the right Riemann sum is an underestimation for the area under the curve. As step size for the Riemann sum \(\Delta x = 1\) is used.

Therefore, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=k +1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^3} < \int_k^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^3} dx,\end{aligned}\]

and hence it suffices to find the minimal value of \(k\) such that the integral above is \(\leq\) 20,000.

But the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{k}^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^3} dx = \left[- \frac{1}{2x^2} \right]_k^{\infty} = \frac{1}{2 k ^2}.\end{aligned}\]

Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=k+1}^\infty \frac1{n^3} < \int_k^{\infty} \frac{1}{x^3} dx = \frac{1}{2 k^2} \leq \frac{1}{20000}.\end{aligned}\]

The minimal such \(k\) is \(k=100\) (in fact, for this choice of \(k\), the right \(\leq\) becomes an \(=\)).

Therefore we must take the first 100 terms of the sum for the approximation to be accurate to within 1/20000.
